alert.note: Alert for Elko (Nevada) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued April 29 at 12:58PM PDT until further notice by NWS Elko
info.description: ...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in Nevada... Owyhee River near Mountain City affecting Elko County. Marys River Near Deeth affecting Elko County. Humboldt River At Palisade affecting Eureka County. Salmon Falls Creek Near Salmon Falls Creek near San Jacinto affecting Elko County. .Warm daytime temperatures along with low temperatures remaining above freezing overnight will accelerate snow melt. River flows will increase quickly and could remain high for the next week. For the Marys River...including Charleston, Deeth...elevated river levels are forecast. For the Lower Humboldt...including Palisade, Battle Mountain, Comus...elevated river levels are forecast. For the Salmon Falls Creek...including Salmon Falls Creek near San Jacinto...elevated river levels are forecast. For the Owyhee River...including Wildhorse Dam, Wildhorse, Mountain City...elevated river levels are forecast. ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt continues. * WHERE...Salmon Falls Creek Near Salmon Falls Creek near San Jacinto. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Minor flooding occurs along the banks of Salmon Falls Creek. Water from Salmon Falls Creek begins entering the Salmon Falls Creek rest area along U.S. 93, about 3 miles south of Jackpot, NV. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:45 AM PDT Friday, April 28 the stage was 8.2 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate below flood stage with a maximum value of 9.7 feet late this evening. Additional water rise is likely by Sunday night. - Action stage is 9.0 feet. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a warning. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Sunday afternoon at 200 PM PDT.
